instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A stuck at 5.09V  0.89W and 0.16 amp
threads.message:
This Macbook Came in  when i connect to USB amp meter , its stuck at 5.09V  0.89W and 0.16 amp , I proceeded to open it to check the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> Chips and found at UB300  CB300 was full shorted to Ground , I managed to remove the CB300 and replaced it ,  I plugged again my USB AMP METER and the Behaviour remains the same ,  I tested  CB300 again and  resistance value to ground was normal .366 OHM  , I Thought it might've been CB300 Was probably defective so i went ahead and changed it to a new one and behaviour still the same , So what i did i changed all the 4 CB3215 Chips to new ones and the behaviour never changed I have  measured <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>  and my 5v is there,  when I checked the LDOS 

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.020
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.448
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 3.350
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 1.813

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 1.796
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.023
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 3.355
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 1.804

UB300
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 1.815
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> =0.021
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 3.216
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0.23

UB400
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 1.815
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> =0.230
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 3.216
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> =1.796


I was checking on the forum and seeing that someone else that you are helping is having my same issue , another thing  , since those chips come with strong underfill while removing the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> I lost all the NC's pads and they left no trace at all i am not sure if they are NOT CONNECTED  or please advice 

Thank you

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A stuck at 5.09V  0.89W and 0.16 amp
threads.message:
NC stands for Not Connected, so no problem if these pads have gone.
Be sure all other pads have good trace.

You've got some low readings on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 and UB300.
However, recheck all LDOs in correct manner; diode mode with red probe at ground ALWAYS.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A stuck at 5.09V  0.89W and 0.16 amp
threads.message: Great, I have another know good board here that i was comparing , diode mode readings seem to be fine but the voltages are not i will double check that .

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A stuck at 5.09V  0.89W and 0.16 amp
threads.message: I got it fixed, I went back to double check as you said , I found CB404 Was giving me OL , So I reflow the  UB 400 And everything went in  smoothly fine , thank you so much for your support , the other guy should just change the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> And he should be all good to go.
